title: Gary Neville accuses Leicester City players of coming across as "wholly dishonest" following Claudio Ranieri's sacking
text:
Gary Neville accuses Leicester City players of coming across as "wholly dishonest" following Claudio Ranieri's sacking The Red Devils legend said the idea of players being involved in the Italian's dismissal is "despicable" Share Gary Neville speaks out following the Italian's sacking (Photo: Getty) Share   Thank you for subscribing!   
Gary Neville has accused the Leicester City players of coming across as "wholly dishonest" following Claudio Ranieri's sacking. 
The Italian was sensationally axed last week, just nine months after guiding the Foxes to the Premier League title. 
MirrorSport revealed a number of senior players spoke to the club's owners about Ranieri's future after losing faith in his methods. 
And Neville has hit out at this notion, calling it the most "unsavoury part" of the Italian's sacking. Claudio Ranieri was sensationally axed last week (Photo: Clive Rose) 
"The route from owner to player, around a manager's future, is not a chain of command. It should never be available," said the treble winner on Sky Sports. 
"In the last few days, a couple of players have spoken - and they are stitching themselves up, they are coming across as wholly dishonest. 
"There are a couple more who I would like to hear from. Caretaker boss Craig Shakespeare will oversee Leicester's game with Liverpool (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
"The reality is - if that has happened, I cannot get my head around it. It is despicable. Even if they were asked, stay clear of it. 
"The idea of sticking together, even if you're invited to comment, it is wrong and they will know it's wrong. 
"I would like to think it hasn't happened. Seeing managers sacked is painful enough, if his own players have knifed him in the back, it is the most difficult part." Fans with a banner for former Leicester City manager Claudio Ranieri (Photo: REUTERS) 
The Foxes play their first game against Liverpool on Monday night since the Italian was let go.
